Given the early stage and no competing offers in our inbox, the best move is to reject and preserve the slot for higher-ranked seekers who may apply later.

However, C ranks us #1 and is also highly desired by other companies (Company_C ranks Seeker_C #2; Company_D ranks Seeker_C #3; Company_E ranks Seeker_C #2), so C is likely to secure a good match elsewhere if we don’t accept immediately. Seeker_D also ranks us #1, but is ranked very highly by Company_A (#2) and Company_D (#1), and D’s own preferences place Company_C as #2 and Company_A as #3, so D has strong outside options and may not remain available if we delay. Since Seeker_E (our top choice) and Seeker_B (our #2) did not contact us this round and may be difficult to attract (E ranks us last; B ranks us #2 but may target A first), holding out is risky. Given quota=1 and need to decide now on Seeker_D specifically, accepting Seeker_D secures a top-4 choice and avoids ending unmatched while waiting for unlikely E or uncertain B.
